definitionA: (especially of a will) oral; not written.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Oral; not written.
   2. Publicly or solemnly declaratory.
   3. Nominal; existing only in name.
etymology: First recorded in 1400–50; from Medieval Latin (testāmentum) nuncupātīvum “oral (will),” neuter of Late Latin nuncupātīvus “so-called, nominal,” equivalent to Latin nuncupāt(us), past participle of nuncupāre “to state formally, utter the name of” (probably from unattested nōmicupāre, derivative of nōmiceps “one taking a name,” equivalent to nōmi- combining form of nōmen “name” + -ceps “taker, catcher”); prince ( def ) ) + -īvus -ive ( def )
example: Upon this, Chancellor Kent observed: “I should hope to see one day a law that no nuncupative will should be valid in any case.”

definitionA: showing great enthusiasm for or interest in:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Enthusiastic; keen; eager; showing great interest in something or desire to do something
etymology: First recorded in 1760–70; from French avide, from Latin avidus, equivalent to av(ēre) “to crave” + -idus adjective suffix; -id 4
example: Favorite books can be displayed vertically stacked in between, which makes this a great and thoughtful choice for avid readers.

definitionA: a sheath for a sword or the like.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The sheath of a sword.
<verb>
   1. To put an object (especially a sword) into its scabbard.
etymology: 1250–1300; Middle English scalburde, scauberge (compare Anglo-French escauberz, escauberge, Medieval Latin escauberca ) ≪ dissimilated variant of Old High German *skārberga sword-protection. See shear, harbor
example: Whenever an injustice occurred, Hitchens would declare, “The pen of the Hitch will flash from its scabbard.”

definitionA: a case or covering for the blade of a sword, dagger, or the like.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A holster for a sword; a scabbard.
   2. (by extension) Anything that has a similar shape to a scabbard that is used to hold an object that is longer than it is wide.
   3. The base of a leaf when sheathing or investing a branch or stem, as in grasses.
   4. The insulating outer cover of an electrical cable.
   5. One of the elytra of an insect.
   6. A tight-fitting dress.
   7. The foreskin of certain animals (for example, dogs and horses).
   8. A condom.
<verb>
   1. To put (something such as a knife or sword) into a sheath.
   2. To encase (something) with a protective covering.
   3. Of an animal: to draw back or retract (a body part) into the body, such as claws into a paw.
   4. To thrust (a sharp object like a sword, a claw, or a tusk) into something.
   5. To abandon or cease (animosity, etc.)
   6. To provide (a sword, etc.) with a sheath.
   7. To relieve the harsh or painful effect of (a drug, a poison, etc.).
etymology: before 950; Middle English s ( c ) heth ( e ), Old English scēath; cognate with German Scheide; shed 2
example: The included rugged leather sheath securely attaches to a belt.

definitionA: a sheathlike carrying case for a firearm, attached to a belt, shoulder sling, or saddle.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A case for carrying a tool, particularly a gun, safely and accessibly.
   2. A belt with loops or slots for carrying small tools or other equipment.
<verb>
   1. To put something in a holster.
etymology: 1655–65; < Dutch; cognate with Gothic hulistr, Old Norse hulstr sheath; akin to Old English helan to hide
example: The pistol was in a distinctive holster depicting the American flag and the words “We the People.”

definitionA: something risked or staked on an uncertain event; bet:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Something deposited, laid, or hazarded on the event of a contest or an unsettled question; a bet; a stake; a pledge.
   2. That on which bets are laid; the subject of a bet.
   3. A contract by which two parties or more agree that a certain sum of money, or other thing, shall be paid or delivered to one of them, on the happening or not happening of an uncertain event.
   4. An offer to make oath.
<verb>
   1. To bet something; to put it up as collateral
   2. To suppose; to dare say.
<noun>
   1. Agent noun of wage; one who wages.
etymology: 1275–1325; Middle English wajour, wager solemn pledge < Anglo-French wageure, equivalent to wage ( r ) to pledge ( wage ) + -ure -ure
example: After all, states have bet big on betting and, in most cases, are still waiting for the long-shot wager to pay off.

definitionA: to hit hard, as in boxing or cricket; slug.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A long, tedious walk, or session of work.
   2. An aggressive shot played with little skill.
<verb>
   1. To walk slowly, encountering resistance.
   2. (by extension) To work slowly and deliberately at a tedious task.
   3. To strike something with a heavy blow, especially a ball with a bat.
etymology: First recorded in 1850–55; variant of slug 2
example: The 50 millimeters of foam underfoot also virtually eliminated the chronic knee and hip pain I typically experience after long downhill slogs.

definitionA: a record of events, especially a yearly record, usually in chronological order.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The record of a single event or item.
<noun>
   1. A relation of events in chronological order, each event being recorded under the year in which it happened.
   2. Historical records; chronicles; history.
   3. A periodic publication, containing records of discoveries, transactions of societies, etc.
etymology: 1555–65; (< Middle French ) < Latin annālēs ( librī ) literally, yearly (books), plural of annālis continuing for a year, annual, equivalent to ann ( us ) a year + ālis -al 1
example: Because Patel’s Gawain is “green” himself, the film frames his acceptance of the challenge as a way to have a noble adventure and inscribe his name in the annals of history.

definitionA: having the form of a ring.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Pertaining to, or having the form of, a ring; ring-shaped; in the shape of an annulus.
   2. Banded or marked with circles.
etymology: 1565–75; < Latin annulāris, equivalent to annul ( us ) ring (variant of ānulus ) + -āris -ar 1
example: This improved process of casting may also be employed for objects which do not possess an exactly annular section.

definitionA: feeling, characterized by, or expressing strong displeasure at something considered unjust, offensive, insulting, or base:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Showing anger or indignation, especially at something unjust or wrong.
etymology: First recorded in 1580–90; from Latin indignant- (stem of indignāns, present participle of indignārī “to deem unworthy, take offense”), equivalent to in- in- 3 + dign-, stem of dignus “worthy” + -ant- -ant
example: When I did that last year, the interviewer became indignant, saying that asking why the prior employee left was inappropriate and that I was asking about a private personnel matter.

definitionA: an inexpensive souvenir, trinket, or ornament.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A trinket.
   2. An attractive woman or girl.
etymology: First recorded in 1965–70, Americanism; from Yiddish tshatshke, from Polish czaczko “bibelot, knickknack” (now obsolete; compare modern cacko with same sense, originally dialect); of expressive origin
example: The delicate tea set, the corn husk dolls, the tchotchkes from the Old Country.

definitionA: an ornamental trinket or gimcrack; a bit of bric-a-brac.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A small ornament of minor value.
etymology: 1610–20; gradational compound based on knack in obsolete sense “toy”
example: The next few hours were a flurry of vacuuming and dusting as my mother chain-smoked her way through the house rearranging knickknacks.

definitionA: a small ornament, piece of jewelry, etc., usually of little value.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A small showy ornament or piece of jewelry
   2. A thing of little value; a trifle; a toy.
   3. A three-cornered sail formerly carried on a ship's foremast, probably on a lateen yard.
   4. A knife; a cutting tool.
<verb>
   1. To give trinkets; to court favour.
example: The walls of his office were lined with treasures and trinkets from his travels, which his brother said he used to ease the nerves of his clients.

definitionA: large in quantity or number; abundant; plentiful:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Vast in quantity or number, profuse, abundant; taking place on a large scale.
   2. Having an abundant supply.
   3. Full of thought, information, or matter; exuberant in words, expression, or style.
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; Middle English, from Latin cōpiōsus “plentiful, rich,” from cōpi(a) “wealth” (from co- co- + op(s) “plenty, power, support” + -ia -ia ) + -ōsus -ous
example: In general, larger, lined notebooks work best for school settings where you’ll be taking copious notes throughout the day.

definitionA: to challenge as false (another's statements, motives, etc.); cast doubt upon.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To assault, attack.
   2. To verbally assault, especially to argue against an opinion, motive, or action; to question the truth or validity of.
etymology: 1325–75; Middle English impugnen < Middle French impugner < Latin impugnāre to attack, equivalent to im- im- 1 + pugnāre to fight, derivative of pugnus fist; pugnacious
example: It’s more work for you, of course, but the goal is to ensure your behavior is above reproach while giving Wanda space to prove —or impugn — herself.

definitionA: people, or a group of people, regarded as disreputable or worthless:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The rabble; crowds; the common people.
   2. Sweepings; refuse.
etymology: 1425–75; late Middle English rif and raf every particle, things of small value < Old French rif et raf, formed on rifler to spoil ( rifle 2 ), raffler to ravage, snatch away
example: Then, the specific one that a scientist wants to study is separated from the riffraff by magnets that redirect particles based on their mass and electric charge.

definitionA: to clear from a charge of guilt or fault; free from blame; vindicate.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To clear of or to free from guilt; exonerate.
etymology: First recorded in 1650–60; from Latin exculpātus “freed from blame,” equivalent to ex- ex- 1 + culpātus “blamed” (past participle of culpāre; culpable )
example: In other words, such is the desire which every one has to exculpate himself by blackening his neighbour.

definitionA: pertaining to, resembling, of the nature of, or affected with scrofula.
example: Sheerly by chance, some of those scrofulous churls will have some minor position of power in one institution or another.

definitionA: any of various snaillike terrestrial gastropods having no shell or only a rudimentary one, feeding on plants and a pest of leafy garden crops.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Any of many terrestrial pulmonate gastropod mollusks, having no (or only a rudimentary) shell.
   2. A slow, lazy person; a sluggard.
   3. A bullet or other projectile fired from a firearm; in modern usage, generally refers to a shotgun slug.
   4. A solid block or piece of roughly shaped metal.
   5. A counterfeit coin, especially one used to steal from vending machines.
   6. A shot of a drink, usually alcoholic.
   7. A title, name or header, a catchline, a short phrase or title to indicate the content of a newspaper or magazine story for editing use.
   8. (rarely used) the Imperial (English) unit of mass that accelerates by 1 foot per second squared (1 ft/s²) when a force of one pound-force (lbf) is exerted on it.
   9. A discrete mass of a material that moves as a unit, usually through another material.
   10. A motile pseudoplasmodium formed by amoebae working together.
   11. An accessory to a diesel-electric locomotive, used to increase adhesive weight and allow full power to be applied at a lower speed. It has trucks with traction motors but lacks a prime mover.
   12. (television editing) A black screen.
   13. A piece of type metal imprinted by a linotype machine; also a black mark placed in the margin to indicate an error; also said in application to typewriters; type slug.
   14. A stranger picked up as a passenger to enable legal use of high occupancy vehicle lanes.
   15. (District of Columbia) A hitchhiking commuter.
   16. The last part of a clean URL, the displayed resource name, similar to a filename.
   17. A hindrance, an obstruction.
   18. A ship that sails slowly.
<verb>
   1. To drink quickly; to gulp; to down.
   2. To take part in casual carpooling; to form ad hoc, informal carpools for commuting, essentially a variation of ride-share commuting and hitchhiking.
   3. (of a bullet) To become reduced in diameter, or changed in shape, by passing from a larger to a smaller part of the bore of the barrel.
   4. To move slowly or sluggishly; to lie idle.
   5. To load with a slug or slugs.
   6. To make sluggish.
<noun>
   1. A hard blow, usually with the fist.
<verb>
   1. To hit very hard, usually with the fist.
etymology: First recorded in 1375–1425; late Middle English slugge “sluggard,” from Scandinavian; compare Norwegian (dialectal) sluggje “heavy, slow person”
example: Instead, after the initial slug of snow, they predict a dry slot to punch into the region as temperatures rise while the secondary low forms and exits to our east.
